intro: Pimpinella tragium var. pseudotragium, commonly known as the false cow parsley, is a biennial or short-lived perennial herb native to southern Europe. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescences and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with finely divided, fern-like leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small and white, arranged in flat-topped clusters, and it produces small, oval-shaped fruits known as schizocarps. This variety is often found in disturbed soils and open habitats, such as roadsides and waste areas.
